;

;随着以色列军队加强他们的;加沙地带针对哈马斯的袭击;，华盛顿、联合国、中东及其他地区的外交官已经开始如果巴勒斯坦激进组织被驱逐，他们会权衡“第二天”的选择 - 他们看到的挑战是令人畏惧的。

;

;讨论内容包括向冲突后的加沙部署多国部队，这是一个临时巴勒斯坦领土据知情人士透露，特朗普领导的政府将排除哈马斯政客，为邻国阿拉伯国家提供权宜之计的安全和治理作用，并由联合国对该领土进行临时监督。

;

;这一进程仍处于另一个阶段。美国消息人士称这是一个非正式的“想法浮动阶段”。关键问题包括以色列是否能够像其誓言那样摧毁哈马斯，以及美国及其西方盟国和阿拉伯政府是否会派遣军事人员站在以色列和巴勒斯坦之间，克服长期以来不愿这样做的情况。

;

;白宫周三表示，“没有计划或意图”在加沙部署美军。

;

;随着辩论愈演愈烈，加沙卫生当局表示，已有 9,000 多人在这场冲突中丧生。 25 英里长的狭长地带，是 230 万巴勒斯坦人的家园。加沙一半以上的人口已经流离失所，拥挤的医院缺乏电力和药品，正在拒绝接收伤者，;掘墓人的墓地位置已所剩无几。

;

;目前还不清楚巴勒斯坦权力机构 (PA) 是否在被占领的约旦河西岸部分地区拥有有限的自治权当哈马斯统治加沙时，他能够或愿意控制。美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯周二提出了“重振”巴勒斯坦权力机构的前景，但马哈茂德·阿巴斯总统的政府一直受到腐败和管理不善指控的困扰。

;

;任何试图在巴勒斯坦权力机构中行使权力的实体战后的加沙还必须应对巴勒斯坦人的印象，即它受制于以色列。其对哈马斯的攻势是为了报复 10 月 7 日发生的毁灭性暴乱，当时武装分子在以色列南部杀害了 1,400 人，并劫持了 200 名人质。

;

;即使哈马斯的领导层被推翻，也将是一场灾难。根除加沙居民的亲武装情绪几乎是不可能的，这增加了针对任何掌权者的新袭击的威胁，包括自杀性爆炸。

;

;“如果以色列成功镇压哈马斯，我认为它会继续下去。美国前中东谈判代表亚伦·戴维·米勒 (Aaron David Miller) 表示：“那里要建立一个合法且有效的治理结构是极其困难的。”

;

;“‘次日’演习现在就开始了。米勒说。

;

;随着以色列扩大对加沙的空中、陆地和海上攻击，讨论不断增加，但美国官员认为以色列的;迄今为止未能阐明结局;。

;

;人们越来越认识到，重建加沙需要大量国际援助，而在哈马斯仍掌权的情况下，西方政府几乎不可能获得此类援助。

;

;周四出发前的片刻在以色列和约旦之行期间，布林肯表示，他在该地区的会议不仅会讨论“具体步骤”，以;最大限度地减少对加沙平民的伤害;，但也提出了战后规划问题。

;

;“我们关注这一天。我们还需要关注后天，”布林肯告诉记者。他说，持久和平的基础是最终实现巴勒斯坦建国的道路，而以色列总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡长期以来一直抵制这一目标。

;

;美国官员私下表示，他们和以色列同行已经讨论了从华盛顿入侵伊拉克和阿富汗的失误中汲取教训，以及对接下来发生的事情缺乏准备的问题。

;

;美国官员已讨论建立一支多国部队来维持秩序。其组成可能包括欧洲或阿拉伯国家，但没有政府公开表示有兴趣加入这样一支部队。

;

;美国总统乔·拜登于 2021 年结束了华盛顿在阿富汗长达两年的军事存在的特朗普，在寻求 2024 年连任时，不太可能愿意在新的外国冲突中卷入直接军事行动。

;

;一些政策分析师还提出了向加沙部署一支联合国支持的部队的想法——要么是一支正式的联合国维和部队，就像在以色列-黎巴嫩边境那样，要么是一支经联合国批准的多国部队。

;

;但外交官们称联合国尚未就这一举措进行讨论，这需要联合国安理会 15 个成员国达成一致。

;

;此类任务往往面临重大障碍。 2022年10月，海地请求国际社会帮助打击暴力团伙。一年后，联合国安理会授权了一项外国安全任务，但由于难以找到愿意领导该任务的国家而被推迟。肯尼亚加强了行动，但海地仍在等待特派团的到来。

;

;使事情变得更加复杂的是，以色列可能会反对联合国发挥任何安全作用，特别是在以色列官员谴责联合国秘书长安东尼奥·古特雷斯称哈马斯袭击事件之后10 月 7 日发生的事件“并非凭空发生。”

;

;以色列预计会发生一场长期战争，但表示无意重新占领加沙。

;

;外部专家，其中一些人在美国政策制定者正在权衡战后加沙的面貌。

;

;如果哈马斯能够被剥夺“否决权”并且加沙实现非军事化，“这可能会开启前中东谈判代表兼白宫顾问丹尼斯·罗斯表示，这是建立一个由技术官僚巴勒斯坦领导的政府组成的临时政府的方式，该政府在某种国际和/或地区保护伞下运作。

;

;他说，细节需要以美国为首，与巴勒斯坦权力机构和其他对中东稳定感兴趣的主要参与者进行复杂的接触。

;

;但是，为了使这项工作发挥作用，以色列必须限制时间罗斯表示，必须为其在加沙的军事存在制定框架，否则任何新的管理机构在其人民眼中都可能缺乏合法性。

;

;罗斯和华盛顿近东研究所的两名同事撰写的一篇文章政策提出，一旦以色列撤军，加沙的安全将由“与以色列达成和平协议的五个阿拉伯国家组成的联盟——埃及、约旦、阿拉伯联合酋长国、巴林和摩洛哥”提供。

;

;但有人怀疑这样的安排能否达成。

;

;“阿拉伯国家不会派出军队去杀害巴勒斯坦人，”现任卡内基基金会的前谈判代表米勒说。华盛顿国际和平。

;;美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯周四（11 月 2 日）表示，他将在访问以色列期间讨论应采取的“具体步骤”，以最大程度地减少对加沙平民的伤害，因为人们对以色列轰炸加沙飞地伤亡人数激增的担忧日益加剧。小>;
;

;以色列表示，它已经包围了加沙地带最大的城市，也是其消灭哈马斯的重点，美国将敦促总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡同意暂停战斗，以允许< a href="/world/middle-east/what-is-人道主义-situation-besieged-gaza-2023-11-02/">;向巴勒斯坦飞地提供援助;。

;

;随着冲突已接近第四周，美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯将在一个月内第二次访问以色列，并会见;内塔尼亚胡;以色列军队与哈马斯武装分子作战，哈马斯武装分子通过地下隧道的打了就跑的袭击进行了反击。

;

;“我们是在战斗最激烈的时候。我们取得了令人印象深刻的成功，并且已经通过了加沙城的郊区。我们正在前进，”内塔尼亚胡在军方表示已经包围了这片海滨飞地的主要城市后发表的一份声明中说道。

;

;布林肯离开华盛顿前往中东时，他表示将讨论具体措施，以最大程度地减少;对加沙平民的伤害;。白宫，与此同时，表示任何战斗暂停都应该是暂时的和局部的，并坚称他们不会阻止以色列自卫。

;

;巴勒斯坦平民伤亡不断增加，;粮食、水、药品和燃料;，全球领导人更加强烈地呼吁暂停战斗或停火。

;

;以色列驳回了这些呼吁，称其目标是哈马斯战士，并指责这些战士故意隐藏在居民和民用建筑中。白宫也拒绝了停火的呼吁。

;

;加沙卫生当局表示，自以色列对拥有 230 万人的飞地发动袭击以来，加沙至少已有 9,061 人死亡，以报复哈马斯武装分子对以色列南部发动的致命袭击。

;

;联合国独立专家警告称，加沙的巴勒斯坦人正处于;" “种族灭绝的严重风险”。;

;

;“我们呼吁以色列及其盟友同意立即停火。我们的时间不多了，”联合国特别报告员小组在一份声明中表示。

;

;以色列驻日内瓦联合国代表团称报告员的言论“令人遗憾且深感担忧”，并指责哈马斯对平民造成的伤害。联合国秘书长安东尼奥·古特雷斯发言人斯特凡·杜雅里克 (Stéphane Dujarric) 表示，种族灭绝的判定只能由联合国相关司法机构做出。

;

;以色列称哈马斯杀害了 1,400 人，其中大部分是平民，并夺走了更多人的生命。 10 月 7 日的袭击造成超过 240 名人质，这是该国 75 年历史上伤亡最惨重的一天。

;

;白宫周四表示，正在调查冲突中的一系列暂停情况。

;

;美国国家安全发言人表示：“我们正在尝试做的是探索尽可能多地暂停的想法，以继续提供援助，并继续努力将包括人质在内的人员安全救出。”约翰·柯比告诉记者。

;

;布林肯还定于周六在安曼会见约旦外交部长艾曼·萨法迪。萨法迪在一份声明中表示，以色列必须结束对加沙的战争，他称以色列在加沙轰炸平民和实施围困，犯下了战争罪行。

;

;海湾阿拉伯国家阿拉伯联合酋长国（阿联酋）警告说周五，中东的紧张局势“接近沸点”，并且正在“不懈地”努力实现立即全面的人道主义停火。

;

;“地区蔓延和进一步升级的风险是真实存在的外交部长努拉·卡比 (Noura al-Kaabi) 在阿布扎比举行的一次会议上表示： /p>;

;在加沙发生剧烈爆炸时，以色列军方发言人丹尼尔·哈加里少将告诉记者，以色列“部队完成了对加沙城的包围，该城是哈马斯恐怖组织的焦点”。

;

;以色列军事工程总监伊多·米兹拉希准将表示，部队遇到了地雷和诱杀装置。

;

;“哈马斯已经做好了充分的准备，”他说。

;

;阿布·乌拜达 (Abu Ubaida)哈马斯武装派系发言人周四在电视讲话中表示，以色列在加沙的死亡人数远高于军方公布的数字。他说：“你们的士兵将带着黑色袋子返回。”

;

;以色列表示，自周五地面行动扩大以来，已损失 18 名士兵，并杀死了数十名武装分子。

;

;哈马斯及其盟军;伊斯兰圣战战士;正从隧道中涌出，居民们说，他们向坦克开火，然后又消失在网络中，两个组织的视频也显示了这一点。

;

;两名不愿透露姓名的美国官员表示，美国正在加沙上空驾驶情报收集无人机，以帮助寻找人质。其中一名官员表示，他们已经执行无人机飞行一个多星期了。

;

;;从加沙到埃及的拉法过境点;将于周五开放第三天，根据卡塔尔斡旋的协议旨在进行有限的疏散允许一些外国护照持有者、他们的家属和一些受伤的加沙人离开飞地。

;

;据边境官员称，前两天有 700 多名外国公民经拉法前往埃及。数十名重伤的巴勒斯坦人也将穿越。以色列要求外国派遣;医疗船;

;

;泰国表示，它正在与伊朗和其他可以与哈马斯联系的政府保持联系，以安全释放被扣为人质的近二十名泰国国民。

;

;泰国外交部部长帕恩普雷·巴希达-努卡拉 (Parnpree Bahiddha-Nukara) 周五表示，与哈马斯关系密切的伊朗已承诺帮助谈判。

;

;加沙 35 家医院中有超过三分之一无法运转，许多医院变成了临时难民营。

;

;巴勒斯坦人医疗援助慈善机构表示，“情况是灾难性的”，并描述了拥挤的走廊和许多失去亲人且无家可归的医务人员。

;

;Since the plan was unveiled in December, the yen has lost 10% of its value against the dollar, forcing Tokyo to reduce its ambitious defence procurement plan, which was then-calculated to cost $320 billion, the sources said.

;Reuters interviewed three government officials with direct knowledge of defence procurement and five industry sources, who said Japan will begin cutting back on aircraft purchases in 2024, the second year of the build-up, due to the weak yen.

;

;Unlike large companies that do business overseas, Japan's defence ministry does not hedge against currency rate fluctuations, one of the government officials said, meaning it has few means to mitigate the rising cost in yen of Tomahawk cruise missiles and F-35 stealth fighters.

;

;Any sign that Prime Minister Fumio Kishida will get less bang than anticipated from his military spending binge could stir unease in Washington about its key ally's ability to help contain Beijing, said Christopher Johnstone, Japan chair at the Center for Strategic and International Studies think tank.

;

;"For now, the impact is modest. But there is no question that a long-term depreciation of the yen would sap the impact of Japan's build-up, and force cuts and delays to key acquisitions," said Johnstone, a former National Security Council director for East Asia in the Biden administration.

;

;Japan's Ministry of Defence said it does not discuss details of procurement planning when contacted for comment.

;China, which has not ruled out using military force to bring Taiwan under its control, has expressed concern about Japan's military spending plans, accusing it of displaying a "Cold War mentality."

;

;With the cuts in its spending power, Japan decided to prioritize spending on advanced US-made frontline weapons such as missiles that could halt advancing Chinese forces, the eight people said. That means less money on support aircraft and other secondary kit, much of it made by Japanese companies, they said.

;

;In December, defence ministry officials discussed an order for 34 twin-rotor Chinook transport helicopters at roughly 15 billion yen per aircraft, two of the sources said.

;

;In the defence budget request for the year starting April 2024, which was published in August, that order was halved to 17 because the cost of the aircraft had jumped by around 5 billion yen each since December. About half that increase was due to the weak yen, said one of the government sources, who was directly involved in those discussions.

;

;The aircraft are assembled by Kawasaki Heavy Industries ;(7012.T); under license from Boeing Co ;(BA.N);. A Kawasaki spokesperson confirmed that the unit cost increase had resulted in a reduction in the Chinook order.

;

;Japan also scrapped a plan to buy two ShinMaywa Industries ;(7224.T); US-2 seaplanes used for search and rescue missions after the price per aircraft almost doubled to 30 billion yen compared with three years ago, said two other people familiar with the spending plans.

;

;"The price has risen considerably, and that is because the weaker yen and inflation have significantly pushed up costs," a company spokesperson said. She declined to comment on whether the defence ministry had dropped an order for the seaplane.

;

;For Kishida, who must grapple with rival ruling-party factions that are sparring over whether to borrow money or hike taxes to pay for his defence build-up, pruning equipment purchases may be politically less fraught than asking lawmakers for top-ups, analysts said.

;

;"Whether Kishida decides to increase the budget or do nothing will depend on his support rate in Japan," said Yoji Koda, a retired Maritime Self Defense Force admiral, who commanded the Japanese fleet. He expects the Japanese leader to opt for procurement cuts or delays because it's easier than convincing taxpayers to fork out more money.

;

;But, by sidestepping that challenge, Kishida is also inviting a backlash from Japanese companies that worry they will bear the brunt of cuts to ensure Tokyo can afford Raytheon ;(RTX.N); Tomahawks and the F-35 jets it has ordered from Lockheed Martin ;(LMT.N);.

;

;In a sign of growing discontent, the Japan Business Federation, the country's most influential corporate lobby, joined several defence industry associations in October to press the defence ministry for extra military procurement funds in a supplementary budget now before parliament, one of the sources said.

;

;A ministry spokesperson confirmed the companies delivered a letter on Oct 25 to Defence Minister Minoru Kihara urging the government to proceed with the defence procurement as planned.

;

;The business lobby declined to comment.

;

;Defence firms will struggle to get more money because the government will want to hold off on adding to the 43 trillion-yen plan to see if the currency situation changes, said Kevin Maher at NMV Consulting in Washington, who headed the US State Department's Office of Japan Affairs.

;

;"If they think it will impact capabilities then it is possible, but I think at the earliest that would be in the next to last year of the five-year plan," he said.

;

;

;FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried was found guilty on Thursday of stealing from customers of his now-bankrupt cryptocurrency exchange in one of the biggest financial frauds on record, a verdict that cemented the ;31-year-old; former billionaire's fall from grace.

;

;A 12-member jury in Manhattan federal court convicted Bankman-Fried on all seven counts he faced after a ;monthlong trial; in which prosecutors made the case that he looted $8 billion from the exchange's users out of sheer greed.

;

;The verdict came just shy of one year after FTX filed for bankruptcy in a ;swift corporate meltdown; that shocked financial markets and erased his estimated $26 billion personal fortune.

;

;The jury reached the verdict after just over four hours of deliberations. Bankman-Fried, who had pleaded not guilty to two counts of fraud and five counts of conspiracy, stood facing the jury with his hands clasped in front of him as the verdict was read.

;

;The conviction was a victory for the US Justice Department and ;Damian Williams;, the top federal prosecutor in Manhattan, who made rooting out corruption in financial markets one of his top priorities.

;

;"The crypto industry might be new, the players like Sam Bankman-Fried may be new, but this kind of fraud is as old as time and we have no patience for it," Williams told reporters outside the courthouse.

;

;Once the darling of the crypto world, Bankman-Fried - who was known for his mop of unkempt curly hair and for wearing shorts and T-shirts rather than business attire - joins the likes of admitted Ponzi schemer Bernie Madoff and "Wolf of Wall Street" fraudster Jordan Belfort as notable people convicted of major US financial crimes.

;

;US District Judge Lewis Kaplan set Bankman-Fried's sentencing for March 28, 2024. The Massachusetts Institute of Technology graduate could face decades in prison.

;

;His defense lawyer Mark Cohen said in a statement that he was "disappointed" but respected the jury's decision.

;

;"Mr. Bankman-Fried maintains his innocence and will continue to vigorously fight the charges against him," he said.

;

;After Kaplan left the courtroom, Cohen put his arm around Bankman-Fried as they spoke at the defense table.

;

;As Bankman-Fried was led away by members of the US Marshals service, he turned around and nodded at his parents, the Stanford Law School professors Joseph Bankman and Barbara Fried, who were seated in the courtroom audience's front row. Fried looked toward him and crossed her arm across her chest.

;

;Bankman-Fried is set to go on trial next March on a second set of charges brought by prosecutors earlier this year, including for alleged foreign bribery and bank fraud conspiracies.

;

;Bankman-Fried's was the first of several blockbuster cases Williams brought against former high-flying cryptocurrency executives to go to trial. Several crypto companies went bankrupt last year after the prices of bitcoin and other digital assets collapsed following a years-long boom.

;

;Prosecutors argued during the trial that Bankman-Fried siphoned money from FTX to his crypto-focused hedge fund, Alameda Research, despite proclaiming on social media and in television advertisements that the exchange prioritized the safety of customer funds.

;

;Alameda used the money to pay its lenders and to make loans to Bankman-Fried and other executives - who in turn made speculative venture investments and donated upwards of $100 million to US political campaigns in a bid to promote cryptocurrency legislation the defendant viewed as favorable to his business, according to prosecutors.

;

;Bankman-Fried took the calculated risk of testifying in his own defense over three days near the close of trial after three former members of his inner circle testified against him.他面临检方咄咄逼人的盘问，常常避免直接回答最具挑战性的问题。

;

;他作证说，虽然他在运营 FTX 时犯了错误，例如没有组建风险管理团队，但他没有窃取客户资金。他表示，他认为 Alameda 向 FTX 借款是被允许的，直到两家公司倒闭前不久才意识到其债务增长了多少。

;

;“我们认为我们也许能够打造市场上最好的产品，”班克曼-弗里德作证说。 “结果基本上与此相反。”

;

;检察官有不同的看法。

;

;“他没有讨价还价，让他的三名忠诚的副手采取这一立场并告诉你真相。 ：他是那个有计划、有动机、有贪婪地掠夺 FTX 客户存款（数十亿美元）的人，目的是给自己带来金钱、权力和影响力。他认为这些规则不适用于他。他认为他检察官丹妮尔·沙逊 (Danielle Sassoon) 周四告诉陪审团。

;

;陪审团听取了 15 天的证词。 Former Alameda CEO ;Caroline Ellison; and former FTX executives Gary Wang and Nishad Singh, testifying for the prosecution after entering guilty pleas, said he directed them to commit crimes, including helping Alameda loot FTX and lying to lenders and investors about the companies' finances.

;

;The defense argued the three, who have not yet been sentenced, falsely implicated Bankman-Fried in a bid to win leniency at sentencing. Prosecutors may ask Kaplan to take their cooperation into account in deciding their punishment.

;

;Bankman-Fried has been jailed since August after Kaplan revoked his bail, having concluded he likely tampered with witnesses.
